Situation1: A rarely used machine shows an intermittent glitch during a slow production period.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story:
I was hunched over the old packaging machine, squinting at the control panel as it flickered with another cryptic error. The plant was quiet—production was slow, and this machine hadn’t been used in weeks, but my supervisor wanted it ready “just in case.” I was deep into diagnostics, wires and manuals spread around me, when the building alarms blared. My phone buzzed with a flash-flood warning; outside, I could see water pooling along the curb, creeping higher with every minute.

As a repairer, I knew I was expected to stay, to find the source of the glitch and get the machine running. But as a citizen, I felt the weight of responsibility: the city needed everyone to evacuate, to help neighbors, to keep the streets clear for emergency crews. My hands shook as I weighed the demands—my job’s expectation to fix the machine, my duty to the community’s safety. The alarms echoed in my ears, and I stood frozen, torn between the humming machine and the rising water outside.
